section.title: Docker EE 2.0 and Kubernetes
section.p: Docker Enterprise Edition (EE) 2.0 is the only platform that manages and secures applications on Kubernetes in multi-Linux, multi-OS and multi-cloud customer environments. With Docker EE 2.0, you get simplified workflows for the day-to-day management of a Kubernetes environment while still having access to native Kubernetes APIs, CLIs, and interfaces.
section.note: Docker EE 2.0 installs Kubernetes version 1.8. In this release, UCP uses its own RBAC system which is not compatible with Kubernetes RBAC.
section.p:

A sample Kubernetes application has been documented in the section to facilitate verification of the deployed playbooks and configuration. This example is also useful for exploring the new Kubernetes-specific features in the latest Splunk and Sysidg offerings.
section.note: The verion of kubectl used to access the Kubernetes cluster needs to be 1.10 or below. The current release of kubectl is not compatible with the version of Kubernetes (1.8) shipped with Docker EE 2.0.

section.title: Splunk 7.1.2 and Kubernetes
section.p: This minor update to Splunk Enterprise supports monitoring of Kubernetes logs and metrics. Kubernetes metadata is collected by a universal forwarder implemented as a Deployment (with just one replica), while logs are collected by a universal forwarder running on each Kubernetes node using a DaemonSet. The integration leverages the open-source Splunk IT Monitoring and Troubleshooting project at .
This update also includes new versions of Splunk software components - see the section on installing the Splunk App for Windows Infrastructure and its dependencies here.

section.title: Sysdig and Kubernetes
section.p: Sysdig now supports the monitoring of Kubernetes clusters and the playbooks have been updated to make use of this new functionality. See the section for more information.

section.title: Prometheus and Grafana
section.p: Prometheus has been updated to version v2.3.2 while Grafana is now at version 5.2.3
section.note: Prometheus and Grafana do not currently support monitoring Kubernetes worker nodes in this solution and so can only be used in conjunction with Docker swarm deployments.
